dublin_core.dcvalue: We compared telemedicine with a conventional outpatient continence service CS in community dwelling older women with urge or stress incontinence After an initial biofeedback assisted pelvic floor muscle training session subjects were randomized to behavioural training for eight weeks via the CS n 27 or a telemedicine continence programme TCP n 31 Participants in both treatment groups experienced significant improvement in their symptoms namely a reduction in the number of daily incontinence episodes PUnder0 001 and voiding frequency PUnder0 001 while the volume of urine at each micturition increased PUnder0 005 Pelvic floor muscle strength as measured by the Oxford Score also improved PUnder0 005 There were no significant differences in outcomes between the two groups Thus our findings suggest that videoconferencing is as effective as conventional methods in the management of urinary incontinence
Management of urinary incontinence in older women using videoconferencing versus conventional management: a randomized controlled trial.
